abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third National Program
            for Community Empowerment in Rural Areas Project for
            Indonesia were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, risk
            to development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: capacity
            building of an implementing agency responsible for a
            nationwide Community-Driven Development (CDD) program
            requires substantial time and effort. Capacity building of
            communities is a long-term and iterative process which over
            time may lead to inclusive and transparent decision making.
            Project guidelines (procurement, financial management,
            implementation cycle, etc) have to evolve to take into
            account changing community competencies. Project managers
            must avoid to overload such guidelines and to make them too
            bureaucratic. A robust Management Information System (MIS)
            is essential for a nationwide CDD program. Although the
            project was able to monitor progress against its Key
            Performance Indicator (KPIs) by surveys and studies
            (augmented by processed MIS data), a publicly accessible
            system that presents reliable and regularly updated
            information is needed to instill a culture of accountability
            and transparency at all levels of project implementation.
            Pre-financing of block grants by Government of Indonesia
            (GoI) is effective. This approach was pioneered by the
            project and resulted in a significant reduction in delays in
            disbursement of block grants compared to Program Nasional
            Pemberdayaan Masyarakat (PNPM) rural first and second. The
            quality of facilitators is the main driver of
            community-based project implementation quality.
